member.name: T:NationalInstruments.NetworkVariable.Browser
member.summary: Provides methods to discover information about what network variable items are available on the network.

remarks.para: The class discovers items that cannot be accessed by other classes in the network variable class libraries. overcomes the limitations of the browsing functionality provided by the class, and you can use the class to discover network variable items on remote machines. However, all information discovered by the class is read-only, and you can use the class only to determine the type and name of a network variable item.

The browser treats the elements of the network variable hierarchy as items. For example, machines, processes, and network variables are considered individual items by the browser. Items are represented by objects. Some items, such as processes, can contain other items. You can browse for these items by calling one of the overloads of with a parameter that represents the item you are interested in. When this documentation refers to an item, this term can apply to any network variable item unless otherwise specified.
remarks.note: Network variable processes that have not been started are not visible to the class.

Using the class simultaneously with the creation functionality provided by the , , , and classes can lead to undesired results. If you instantiate a , then create a process or variable, the might throw a that indicates "The socket was closed by the remote peer." There is an unpredictable delay between when an item is created and when it is available for browsing. National Instruments recommends you create instances of the class after any creation operations have completed to avoid this error.

member.seealso: Key Measurement Studio Network Variable .NET Library Features

remarks.para:
Normally, the class only returns machines that are in your local subnet. If you want to browse machines that are not part of your local network, use this method to register the machine first. After the machine is registered, the class and the
list the registered machine as if it were part of your local subnet.
remarks.note: The method performs no validation. If the specified machine name is invalid or no machine with the specified name or IP address can be reached, the method returns a for that machine, but attempts to browse the machine's items will fail.

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.NetworkVariable.Browser.GetSubitems(NationalInstruments.NetworkVariable.BrowserItem)
member.summary: Gets the subitems of a specific item.
member.param: The that has subitems listed.
member.returns: An array of objects that represent the subitems of . This array has zero elements if there are no subitems.
member.exception: An unexpected error occurred. Check the property of the exception for more information.

exception.para: The specified item could not be found.

remarks.para: Network variable processes that have not been started are unavailable to the class; you cannot browse these items.
remarks.note: Due to a limitation in the class library, the name of objects must be converted from a .NET Unicode string to an ANSI string. This conversion is done by using the system default code page to map each Unicode character to an ANSI character. If has a name that contains unmappable characters or if any of the returned objects have a name that contains unmappable characters, the unmappable characters are replaced with a substitution character. For more information, refer to Unicode Support in the Network Variable Class Library.

member.example:
The following example application demonstrates using the method to view all network variables that are currently accessible.
Imports NationalInstruments.NetworkVariable
Module ListVariablesExample
Sub Main() Dim browser As New Browser() ListVariables(browser, browser.RemoteRoot) browser.Dispose() End Sub
Sub ListVariables(ByVal browser As Browser, ByVal rootItem As BrowserItem) If rootItem.ItemType = BrowserItemType.Item Then Console.WriteLine(rootItem.Path) Else Dim items() As BrowserItem = browser.GetSubitems(rootItem)
For Each item As BrowserItem In items ListVariables(browser, item) Next End If End Sub
End Module
member.seealso: Key Measurement Studio Network Variable .NET Library Features

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.NetworkVariable.Browser.GetSubitems(System.String)
member.summary: Gets the subitems of the network variable item at the specified path.
member.param: The path of a network variable item.
member.returns: An array of objects that represent the subitems of the item at .
member.exception: The item specified by does not exist.
An unexpected error occurred. Check the property of the exception for more information.

remarks.para: This method is more convenient than the overload of that takes a parameter when you want to browse an item that is under several other items.

The parameter is expected to be in a format similar to that of network share items. The following table demonstrates some valid paths.
Path Item path represents
\\LineMonitor
A machine named "LineMonitor".
\\localhost\TestProc
A process on the local machine named "TestProc".
\\DataCollector01\Temperature\Sensor01
A variable named "Sensor01" in a process named "Temperature" on a machine named "DataCollector01".
\\192.168.1.15\Temperature\Sensor01
A variable named "Sensor01" in a process named "Temperature" on a machine that has the IP address 192.168.1.15.
remarks.note: Due to a limitation in the class library, the name of objects must be converted from a .NET Unicode string to an ANSI string. This conversion is done by using the system default code page to map each Unicode character to an ANSI character. If any of the returned objects have a name that contains unmappable characters, the unmappable characters are replaced with a substitution character. If contains unmappable characters, the substitution may cause the class to find the wrong item or report that the item is not found. For more information, refer to Unicode Support in the Network Variable Class Library.

member.example:
The following example demonstrates browsing network variable items by using the path to the parent item.
Dim browser As New Browser() Dim children As BrowserItem() = browser.GetSubitems("\\\\127.0.0.1\\System") browser.Dispose()
If children.Length = 0 Then Console.WriteLine("There are no items in the System process.") Else Console.WriteLine("Items in the System process:") For Each item As BrowserItem In children Console.WriteLine(item.Path) Next End If
member.seealso: Key Measurement Studio Network Variable .NET Library Features

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.NetworkVariable.Browser.GetSubitemsAsync(NationalInstruments.NetworkVariable.BrowserItem,System.Object)
member.summary: Asynchronously gets the subitems of the specified network variable item.
member.param: The that has subitems listed.
An object that is passed to the method that is invoked when the asynchronous operation completes.

remarks.para:
Use this method when you do not want a browsing operation to block. Each call to this method executes the method on a thread pool thread. When the operation completes, the event is raised. Use the argument provided by this event to determine which operation completed and the results of the operation. The property identifies which operation completed. If an exception is thrown by the browse operation, the exception is stored in the
property. If this property is , then
contains the subitems of .

The parameter enables you to identify which operation raised the event if you have made multiple calls to . can be . When multiple calls to are made, the order in which the calls complete is undefined. When you handle the event, the object specified by is stored in the property of the event handler's argument. National Instruments recommends that you pass a unique object as the parameter for each call to , or it is impossible to determine which call has completed.
remarks.note: Due to a limitation in the class library, the name of objects must be converted from a .NET Unicode string to an ANSI string. This conversion is done by using the system default code page to map each Unicode character to an ANSI character. If has a name that contains unmappable characters or if any of the returned objects have a name that contains unmappable characters, the unmappable characters are replaced with a substitution character. For more information, refer to Unicode Support in the Network Variable Class Library.

member.example:
The following example application demonstrates how to start two simultaneous browse operations and determine which operation has completed. To execute it, create a new console application and paste the following code in the generated class.
Imports NationalInstruments.NetworkVariable Imports System.Threading
Module Module1
' These objects are used to identify the individual operations. Private ReadOnly _machinesId As New Object() Private ReadOnly _processesId As New Object()
Private _flag As New AutoResetEvent(False)
Sub Main() Dim eventsCounted As Integer = 0
Dim browser As New Browser() AddHandler browser.GetSubitemsCompleted, AddressOf HandleBrowseCompleted
browser.GetSubitemsAsync(browser.RemoteRoot, _machinesId) browser.GetSubitemsAsync(browser.LocalRoot, _processesId)
' Wait until both events have been handled. While eventsCounted < 2 _flag.WaitOne() eventsCounted += 1 End While
browser.Dispose() End Sub
Private Sub HandleBrowseCompleted(ByVal sender As Object, ByVal e As GetSubitemsCompletedEventArgs) If e.Error Is Nothing Then Dim message As String
' Output a message based on which operation has completed. If e.UserState Is _machinesId Then message = String.Format("There are {0} machines available.", e.Items.Length) Else message = String.Format("There are {0} processes on this machine.", e.Items.Length) End If
Console.WriteLine(message) Else Console.WriteLine("There was an error:") Console.WriteLine(e.Error.ToString()) End If
_flag.Set() End Sub
End Module

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.NetworkVariable.NetworkVariableBindingBase.Location
member.summary: Gets or sets the path name of the network variable.
member.value: The path name of the network variable. The default value is .

remarks.para:
The format of the is similar to the format of items on network shares and is not case-sensitive. The following are examples:
\\localhost\my_process\my_variable
\\192.168.1.100\my_process\my_variable
\\test_machine.my_network.com\my_process\my_variable
\\localhost\system\my_variable
If you specify a new variable in the system process, such as \\localhost\system\my_variable, then the variable is implicitly created and can hold values of any type.
remarks.note: Due to a limitation in the class library, string values must be converted from a .NET Unicode string to an ANSI string. This conversion is done by using the system default code page to map each Unicode character to an ANSI character. If the process name or variable name contains characters that cannot be converted using the system default code page, trying to call methods, get properties, or set properties may throw an exception. For more information, refer to Unicode Support in the Network Variable Class Library.

member.remarks: Due to a limitation in the class library, the name of objects must be converted from a .NET Unicode string to an ANSI string. member.name: P:NationalInstruments.NetworkVariable.BrowserItem.ParentItem
member.summary: Gets a that represents the item that contains this item.
member.value: A object that represents the parent of the current object.
member.remarks: If you are iterating over the parent items of an item, be sure to stop iteration if you reach an item with a parent that has as the . The only items that are of this type are and , and neither has a logical parent. The value of for items with an of is undefined.
member.example:
The following example demonstrates a method that examines the parent items of a to determine the machine on which it is hosted.
Public Function GetMachineName(ByVal item As BrowserItem) As String While item.ParentItem.ItemType <> BrowserItemType.Root item = item.ParentItem End While
If item.ParentItem Is Browser.RemoteRoot Then ' If the parent item is the remote root, then the ' current item must be a machine Return item.Name ElseIf item.ParentItem Is Browser.LocalRoot Then ' If the parent item is the local root, then the ' parent item is a machine Return item.ParentItem.Name End If
Return "" End Function

member.name: T:NationalInstruments.NetworkVariable.NetworkVariableStringConverter
member.summary: Provides methods that assist with reading and writing values that contain characters that are not supported by .

remarks.para: This class is intended for use in advanced scenarios where you need to transfer values between machines that have different system default code pages. Having different system default code pages can cause a loss of data. For more information about the causes and symptoms of this data loss, refer to Unicode Support in the Network Variable Class Library.

To use this class, you must use a network variable that you configure to use a array instead of a . When you need to write a value to the network variable, use the method to convert the value into an array, and then write the array. When you read the array from the network variable, use the method to convert the array back into a . uses , an that supports Unicode characters, to convert the values unless you specify a different . If you are using network variables to transfer information between a Measurement Studio application and LabVIEW or LabWindows/CVI, your LabVIEW or LabWindows/CVI application must include code to convert between strings and byte arrays using the appropriate encoding.
remarks.note: The used to convert a into a array must be the same as the used to convert the array back into a , or data may be lost.

member.seealso: Unicode Support in the Network Variable Class Library

member.remarks: The encoding used for the value of is .

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.NetworkVariable.NetworkVariableStringConverter.RequiresConversion(System.String)
member.summary: Determines if you must convert a to a array, to prevent data loss, before using it with a network variable.
member.param: The string to test.
member.returns: if the string will lose data if written to a network variable; otherwise, .

remarks.para: Use this method to determine if you can write a string to a network variable without data loss. If returns , you can prevent data loss by using a network variable configured to use a array and using the method to convert the string into a array. You can convert the array back to a string with the method. Refer to Unicode Support in the Network Variable Class Library for more information.

member.seealso: Unicode Support in the Network Variable Class Library

member.name: T:NationalInstruments.NetworkVariable.ServerProcess

summary.para: Provides methods to create, manipulate, and examine the properties of network variable processes.

remarks.para: Use this class when you want to manipulate several processes quickly or explore the processes available on the local machine. If you want to periodically perform operations on a particular process, consider using the class.
The ServerProcess class can only access network variable processes on the local machine.
remarks.note: The Network Variable server reserves the processes System, FP, LV, and all processes that begin with the NI_ prefix. These processes are reserved for use by National Instruments, are not case-sensitive, and cannot be accessed or manipulated by the class.

member.seealso: Key Measurement Studio Network Variable .NET Library Features

member.name: T:NationalInstruments.NetworkVariable.ServerProcessInfo
member.summary: Represents a network variable process and provides methods for creating, deleting, and manipulating the process.

remarks.para: The class provides similar functionality to the class. Use the class when you perform several operations with a particular process, or if you need to periodically manipulate the process. By creating an instance of the class, you can avoid the need to provide the name of the network variable process with every method call.

The network variables under a process that is not running are not available for use to any network variable readers, writers, or subscribers. Use the and method to control whether a process is running.
The and methods provide a convenient way to create network variables; for advanced configuration of network variables, use the or classes.
remarks.note: The Network Variable server reserves the processes System, FP, LV, and all processes that begin with the NI_ prefix. These processes are reserved for use by National Instruments, are not case-sensitive, and cannot be accessed or manipulated by the class.

member.seealso: Key Measurement Studio Network Variable .NET Library Features

member.name: T:NationalInstruments.NetworkVariable.ServerVariable
member.summary: Defines methods to create and configure network variables.

remarks.para: Use the class when you want to create or configure a variable, but you do not want to work with instances of the class. If you want to periodically reconfigure a network variable, it is more convenient to use an instance of the class, since the process name and variable name do not need to be provided with each method call.

You can use the method to create network variables. To set attributes on the variable, use the override of that takes a parameter. If you are creating many variables, the method is easier and more efficient. To configure a variable that already exists, use methods such as and .
The class can only access network variables on the local machine.
remarks.note: The Network Variable server reserves the processes System, FP, LV, and all processes that begin with the NI_ prefix. These processes are reserved for use by National Instruments, are not case-sensitive, and cannot be accessed or manipulated by the class.

member.seealso: Key Measurement Studio Network Variable .NET Library Features

member.name: T:NationalInstruments.NetworkVariable.ServerVariableInfo
member.summary: Represents a network variable and provides methods to create, delete, and configure the variable.

remarks.para: The class is useful for when you need to periodically manipulate a network variable. Since it stores and , you do not need to provide this information to each method call as with the methods provided by the class.

A object does not require the variable it represents to exist. When is called, the current property values of the object are used to create the variable. If the network variable exists when a object is created, the only action that affects the variable is setting properties on the object. For example, if a network variable exists and you use the constructor overload that takes a parameter, the only properties of the that are used are and . To modify an existing network variable, create an instance of and use its properties to modify the variable.
The class can only represent network variables on the local machine.

The Network Variable server reserves the processes System, FP, LV, and all processes that begin with the NI_ prefix. These processes are reserved for use by National Instruments, are not case-sensitive, and cannot be accessed or manipulated by the class.
remarks.note: If the network variable that a object represents is deleted, no notification is provided. If you need to determine if the network variable is deleted, check the property.

Due to a limitation in the class library, string values must be converted from a .NET Unicode string to an ANSI string. This conversion is done by using the system default code page to map each Unicode character to an ANSI character. If the process name or variable name contains characters that cannot be converted using the system default code page, trying to call methods, get properties, or set properties may throw an exception. For more information, refer to Unicode Support in the Network Variable Class Library.

member.seealso: Key Measurement Studio Network Variable .NET Library Features

member.name: T:NationalInstruments.NetworkVariable.NetworkVariableBufferedSubscriber`1
member.summary: Provides a way to read network variable data from a client side buffer.

remarks.para: reads values from a client side buffer instead of accessing the server over the network for every read. Periodically, the server pushes more values to the buffer of the , which reduces network traffic.
Use to read values from the client side buffer. Use to determine the size of the client side buffer and to return the number of current items in the buffer.
remarks.note:
Network variable performance decreases when machines hosting the reader, writer, and variables are mixed between Logos and LogosXT. Logos is the underlying technology of the NI-Publish Subscribe Protocol (psp:), a National Instruments proprietary protocol for inter-process communication. Network variables in Measurement Studio 8.1.2, LabWindows/CVI 8.5, and LabVIEW 8.5 and later use a more efficient TCP-based implementation of Logos called LogosXT to transfer network variable data. National Instruments recommends that you use LogosXT, which uses by default. Performance is especially degraded when the writer and network variable host use LogosXT and the reader that attempts to read the network variable uses Logos. This issue occurs for all reader classes.
For optimum performance, National Instruments recommends that all machines accessing network variables, including the machine that hosts the variable, should use LogosXT. If using LogosXT on all machines is not possible, you should disable LogosXT. You disable LogosXT by adding a DWORD value named DisablePSPXT to the registry key HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SOFTWARE\National Instruments\LogosXT and setting its value to 1. If you must use a mix of Logos versions, you can reduce the performance loss by using Distributed System Manager. Use Distributed System Manager to configure a sufficiently large server-side buffer for the network variable.

member.seealso: Key Measurement Studio Network Variable .NET Library Features

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.NetworkVariable.NetworkVariableManager.FlushAllConnections(System.TimeSpan)
member.summary: Flushes all pending writes to network variables with the specified timeout.
member.param: The amount of time to wait for the flush operation to complete. If the flush operation does not complete within this time period, a is thrown. To block until the flush completes, specify . If you do not want to wait for the flush to complete, specify .

exception.para: The specified timeout was less than .
The specified timeout is too large.

member.exception: An unexpected error happened. Check the property of the exception for more information.
The specified timeout elapsed before the flush operation could complete.

remarks.para:
By default, all buffers are flushed automatically every 10ms. You can call this method if it is important that a value is written immediately. For example, you may have written a large amount of data to a , and you want to ensure the buffer is written immediately. Calling
resets the 10ms timer.

The method affects all connections that have been made. Throughput may be disrupted by calling this method. Refer to Buffer Flushing Behavior of the Network Variable Class Libraries for more information.

remarks.para: Call this method when your application should not block. Each call to this method executes the method in a separate thread that is automatically allocated from the thread pool. When the asynchronous operation completes, it raises the event. Handle the event to get information about the completed operation from the class. This method times out if the connection is not established within 10 seconds. If a timeout occurs, the event is raised with the property set to .

member.summary: Raises the event.
member.param: A that contains the event data.

note.para: If you override in a derived class, an exception is thrown within your implementation any time you read from or write to a network variable. The underlying network variable library uses a special thread for raising events. This thread is blocked during execution of the method. While the special thread is blocked, some operations in the network variable class library cannot be performed. Consequently, you must not perform any the following operations from the method:

item.description: Connect or disconnect any reader or writer. This includes , , , , and . and
Read or write data.
Create a .
Use a to browse by calling , , , or .
Configure a network variable using , , , or .

note.para: If you need to perform any of these operations in response to the event, use an event handler instead of overriding . Event handlers are called in a way that does not block the special thread and are exempt from these limitations.

member.exception: The type of the is invalid.

remarks.para:
The format of the is similar to the format of items on network shares and is not case-sensitive. The following are examples:
\\localhost\my_process\my_variable
\\192.168.1.100\my_process\my_variable
\\test_machine.my_network.com\my_process\my_variable
\\localhost\system\my_variable
If you specify a new variable in the system process, such as \\localhost\system\my_variable, then the variable is implicitly created and can hold values of any type.
remarks.note: Due to a limitation in the class library, string values must be converted from a .NET Unicode string to an ANSI string. This conversion is done by using the system default code page to map each Unicode character to an ANSI character. If contains characters that cannot be converted, an exception is thrown when you call . For more information, refer to Unicode Support in the Network Variable Class Library.

member.name: T:NationalInstruments.NetworkVariable.NetworkVariableBufferedWriter`1
member.summary: Provides a way to write network variable data to a client side buffer.

remarks.para: writes values to a client side buffer, instead of immediately to the server over the network. The buffering process reduces network traffic. Periodically, the writes the data values in the buffer to the server.

Use or to write data to the client side buffer. You can handle the event to receive notification when the data in the buffer writes to the server. Use to determine the size of the client side buffer and to return the number of current items in the buffer.

member.name: T:NationalInstruments.NetworkVariable.NetworkVariableData`1
member.summary: Encapsulates the raw data value.

remarks.para:
The underlying driver can send data for any of the following reasons:
new data value has become available
data timestamp has been updated
data quality value has been updated
server has encountered an error
Any combination of the four values previously listed may be included in the . For example, you can get a that only contains a value signaling the quality has changed, but not the data.
Check the property to determine if has a value. If is , use to get the raw value. If is , use to get the timestamp value of .

Check to determine if there is quality. Use the property to get information about the quality of the . determines if the value is good. If is , check to determine if a server or device error occurred.

member.name: T:NationalInstruments.NetworkVariable.ReadFailedEventArgs`1
member.summary: Provides data when a data source read fails.
member.remarks: One of the main uses for this event argument class is to specify the return value for the data source when the requested read cannot be completed successfully. To specify a custom return value, set the property. If this value is not set, then the data source attempts to use the of the binding. If neither of these values are set, then the requested read throws an exception.

remarks.para: The method establishes the connection with the current value of the property.

If this is the first time has been called since changing the property, the binding uses the current value of the
property to determine if an action should be taken. If a write should be performed, the current value of the property is written to the network variable. If is , an exception is thrown. On subsequent calls to when has not changed, no additional action is taken.

member.summary: Gets or sets a value that specifies the behavior when it connects to the specified network variable for the first time.
member.value: A value that specifies the desired behavior.

remarks.para: The default value for this property is .

The current value of this property is used when is called for the first time for a particular network variable. Changing the value of this property after the has connected has no effect. If you change the value of the property, this represents a new connection and the current value of this property is used when the binding is connected.
If the value of this property is , you must set to the value that should be written when the connection is made. The binding will not write a value unless is .

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.NetworkVariable.WindowsForms.NetworkVariableBinding.InitialValue
member.summary: Gets or sets a value that is written to the network variable when the binding connects.
member.value: The value that is written to the network variable when the binding connects.

remarks.para: If is not set to a value that indicates a value should be written or is not , this property has no effect. The value of this property should not be .

If the value is invalid for the type of the network variable, a default value will be written. For example, if the network variable's type is and you set to the string "NI", the double value 0.0 will be written to the network variable.

member.name: T:NationalInstruments.NetworkVariable.WindowsForms.NetworkVariableDataSource
member.summary: Represents a set of connections to network variables that can be bound to Windows Forms controls.
member.remarks:
Refer to Using the Measurement Studio Network Variable Data Source in Windows Forms for more information.
If the ninetv.dll file is not present on the system, the class cannot function. Use the
event to detect this scenario.
Due to a limitation in the class library, string values must be converted from a .NET Unicode string to an ANSI string. This conversion is done by using the system default code page to map each Unicode character to an ANSI character. If the process name, variable name, or network variable value contains characters that cannot be converted using the system default code page, an exception may be thrown or you may experience unexpected behavior. For more information, refer to Unicode Support in the Network Variable Class Library.
member.seealso: Key Measurement Studio Network Variable .NET Library Features

member.summary: Occurs when the attempts to connect to a network variable and fails.

remarks.para: When the attempts to connect to a network variable, the connection can fail. This event is raised whenever the connection fails. Use the property of the to determine why the connection failed. This event is raised once per connection that fails.

Handle this event when you want to know why connections are failing; use the
or events to determine when reads or writes are failing.
remarks.note:
If the
property is set to , then you must ensure that the event handler for the
event is set up before the is initialized. This can be done by using the Property Grid of the Windows Forms Designer to set up the event handler.

member.name: E:NationalInstruments.NetworkVariable.WindowsForms.NetworkVariableDataSource.ReadFailed
member.summary: Occurs when the data binding framework requests data from a network variable and the read fails.
member.remarks: The event is raised when the data source is disconnected or the value returned from the read contains no data. When the event is unhandled and the is not set for the binding, an is thrown, if the read fails. When the is set, that value is returned from the read, if it fails. When the event is handled and its is set, that value is returned from the read if it fails. Refer to for more information about the arguments that are passed to the event handler.

member.name: T:NationalInstruments.NetworkVariable.WindowsForms.NetworkVariableBrowserDialog
member.summary: Prompts the user to select a network variable location on the network.

remarks.para: This class provides a way to prompt the user to browse to a network variable location on the subnet. The user can add any machine that is not on the subnet by right-clicking Network Neighborhood and selecting Add Machine. Use this class when you want to allow a user to select a valid network variable location.

Call to display the dialog box. Use the property to find the selected location. determines whether a tooltip containing the data type of the network variable item is displayed. Use the event to customize the tooltip string of each item.

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.NetworkVariable.WindowsForms.NetworkVariableBrowserDialog.SelectedLocation
member.summary: Gets or sets the network variable location selected by the user.
member.value: The location of the network variable first selected in the dialog box or the last network variable location selected by the user. The default value is .

remarks.para: If the property is set before showing the dialog box, that location will be the selected location when the dialog box is displayed using .

The property expects a string in a format similar to network paths and is not case sensitive. If the string is not a valid path to an existing network variable item, the default value will be used. Examples of valid paths are:
\\localhost\my_process\my_variable
\\192.168.1.100\my_process\my_variable
\\test_machine.my_network.com\my_process\my_variable

If the method returns , the user clicked the OK button and the property returns a string containing the location selected by the user. member.name: T:NationalInstruments.NetworkVariable.NetworkVariableReader`1
member.summary: Provides a way to read network variable data on demand.

remarks.para: goes across the network to retrieve the next value from the server every time a read call is issued. Because the network is accessed every time a read is called, network traffic increases. To minimize network traffic, consider using .
Use to read the next value from the server synchronously and to read data asynchronously.
remarks.note:
Network variable performance decreases when machines hosting the reader, writer, and variables are mixed between Logos and LogosXT. Logos is the underlying technology of the NI-Publish Subscribe Protocol (psp:), a National Instruments proprietary protocol for inter-process communication. Network variables in Measurement Studio 8.1.2, LabWindows/CVI 8.5, and LabVIEW 8.5 and later use a more efficient TCP-based implementation of Logos called LogosXT to transfer network variable data. National Instruments recommends that you use LogosXT, which uses by default. Performance is especially degraded when the writer and network variable host use LogosXT and the reader that attempts to read the network variable uses Logos. This issue occurs for all reader classes.
For optimum performance, National Instruments recommends that all machines accessing network variables, including the machine that hosts the variable, should use LogosXT. If using LogosXT on all machines is not possible, you should disable LogosXT. You disable LogosXT by adding a DWORD value named DisablePSPXT to the registry key HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SOFTWARE\National Instruments\LogosXT and setting its value to 1. If you must use a mix of Logos versions, you can reduce the performance loss by using Distributed System Manager. Use Distributed System Manager to configure a sufficiently large server-side buffer for the network variable.

member.seealso: Key Measurement Studio Network Variable .NET Library Features

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.NetworkVariable.NetworkVariableReader`1.#ctor(System.String)
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class with the specified path name.
member.param: The path name of the network variable.

remarks.para:
The format of the is similar to the format of items on network shares and is not case-sensitive. The following are examples:
\\localhost\my_process\my_variable
\\192.168.1.100\my_process\my_variable
\\test_machine.my_network.com\my_process\my_variable
\\localhost\system\my_variable
If you specify a new variable in the system process, such as \\localhost\system\my_variable, then the variable is implicitly created and can hold values of any type.
remarks.note: Due to a limitation in the class library, string values must be converted from a .NET Unicode string to an ANSI string. This conversion is done by using the system default code page to map each Unicode character to an ANSI character. If contains unmappable characters, an exception is thrown when you call . For more information, refer to Unicode Support in the Network Variable Class Library.

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.NetworkVariable.NetworkVariableSubscriber`1.OnDataUpdated(NationalInstruments.NetworkVariable.DataUpdatedEventArgs{`0})
member.summary: Raises the event.
member.param: A that contains the event data.

note.para: If you override in a derived class, an exception is thrown within your implementation any time you read from or write to a network variable. The underlying network variable library uses a special thread for raising events. This thread is blocked during execution of the method. While the special thread is blocked, some operations in the network variable class library cannot be performed. Consequently, you must not perform any the following operations from the method:

item.description: Connect or disconnect any reader or writer. This includes , , , , and . and
Read or write data.
Create a .
Use a to browse by calling , , , or .
Configure a network variable using , , , or .

note.para: If you need to perform any of these operations in response to the event, use an event handler instead of overriding . Event handlers are called in a way that does not block the special thread and are exempt from these limitations.

member.summary: Gets or sets a value that determines whether this flushes its value after each write.
member.value: if the flushes after each write operation; otherwise .
member.exception: An unexpected error happened. Check the exception's message property for more information.

remarks.para: The default value is .

The performance of the class significantly increases when the class flushes all buffers as soon as a write is made. This can increase network activity and lower throughput for your application. If you value throughput over performance, you can set the property to and reduce network traffic. National Instruments recommends that you use when throughput is more important than latency.
